awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Personalized Modeling, Monitoring and Control for Advancing Ventricular Assist Device Therapy in End-stage Heart Failure
awd_abstract_narration:
Annually, about 5.7 million adults in U.S. have heart failure, and the associated cost of health care services to treat heart failure is approximately $30.7 billion. An estimated 150,000 new patients are diagnosed with end-stage heart failure annually. Left Ventricular Assist Device (known as "pacemaker") implantation, as the destination therapy, becomes an important treatment option for end-stage heart failure. However, the implantation has unacceptably high mortality rate. For instance, the 1-year mortality rate is as high as 69%. The risk of implantation varies among patients, and the outcome highly depends on preoperative treatment design and postoperative care. Current therapies are guideline-based and greatly rely on the stage of the disease inferred from patients' symptoms. Individual factors associated to disease etiology and prognosis are often neglected. This project develops a personalized preoperative-assessment and postoperative-control system for: (1) efficient risk evaluation of individual patient; (2) personalized modeling and estimation of a patient's heart function; (3) robust and adaptive control of implanted Left Ventricular Assist Devices. The outcomes from this work can lead to technologies that can revolutionize the end-stage heart failure therapy and benefit the overall population of heart failure patients, which will ultimately advance the health and life quality of the whole society. Broader impact on education includes new curriculum modules, science outreach activities, and active recruitment and involvement of underrepresented groups.

This project will bring statistical inference, personalized cardiac modeling, and adaptive control theory into a unified framework for efficient modeling and analysis of heart condition, as well as a practical infrastructure for effective monitoring and control of LVAD. It will leverage modeling, monitoring, control, and optimization methodologies in personalized diagnosis and therapeutic design of LVAD implantation. In particular, this project will: (1) integrate the probabilistic risk analysis with elastic net regularization to predict implantation risk and survival time; (2) develop a spectral approximation-based surrogate model to efficiently quantify parametric uncertainties and accurately estimate model parameters for personalized cardiac modeling; (3) adaptively tune the LVAD controller through a quadratic optimization procedure to maintain the cardiac output and pressure perfusion within acceptable physiological ranges concerning different physiological activities. The accomplishment of this project will give rise to a new paradigm of personalized risk stratification, treatment planning, and postoperative care for end-stage heart failure patients, as opposed to traditional guideline-based solutions. The methodologies are transformative to various fields that involve risk assessment, image segmentation, computational modeling, and adaptive control. These applications include neural systems, advanced manufacturing and civil infrastructure.

por.por_cntn:
Left ventricular assist device (LVAD) has become an established life-saving therapy for end-stage Heart Failure (HF) patients. It serves as the destination therapy for patients who are not eligible for a heart transplant, or as a bridge-to-transplant (BTT) for patients who are too sick to wait for a donor heart to become available. Although the LVAD technology has been advanced significantly in the past decades, the high mortality and complication rate remains a big concern. The risk of LVAD implantation varies among patients, and the outcome of the implantation relies greatly on patient selection, device reliability, and post-operative care.

This project aims to build an integrated system for pre-operative risk assessment and post-operative health management to advance LVAD therapy for end-stage HF. To achieve the objective, we developed new methodologies to support risk stratification, cardiac modeling, and adaptive LVAD control to aid personalized HF therapy in multiple steps of the clinical operations.

We created a risk prediction model using Electronic Health Records (EHRs) for BTT patients supported by a continuous flow LVAD and identified significant risk factors for waiting-list survival. Our investigation on post-operative risk prediction with EHR data revealed several challenges, that is the EHR data often contains a great number of missing values and missing data imputation introduces uncertainty to risk prediction. Many methods have been developed in the literature to represent data with missing values. However, existing approaches do not perform well on data with a large portion of missing segments. To fill the gap, we developed a new algorithm using Expectation-Maximization (EM) method and Gaussian Process Latent Variable Model to estimate missing segments. To propagate the uncertainty from imputation in risk prediction, we designed a constrained Support Vector Machine with a new penalty term introduced to maximumly capture the uncertainty of the imputed values while minimizing risk prediction errors. The model was tested using Intensive Care Unit (ICU) data from HF patients and showed improved accuracy as compared to the other existing models.

As part of the efforts in personalized cardiac modeling and simulation, we developed a Gaussian process-based stochastic model to simulate cardiac functions in a three-dimensional (3D) finite element mesh. The model can well capture the spatial-temporal propagation of electrical impulses given sensing data at sparse locations, thus showing great potential for tracking cardiac functions in both healthy and ill conditions. To customize the model for individual subjects, we designed a two-stage calibration algorithm to estimate the model parameters using cardiac cell data. An ensemble Kalman Filter was applied in the first stage to track cell membrane potentials, and the outputs from the ensemble Kalman Filter were used to calculate forward prediction for model optimization. The algorithm was validated through multiple simulation designs and showed good accuracy and efficiency.

The goal of adaptive LVAD control is to adjust the pumping speed according to patients' activities. Different physical activities will lead to different heart rate (HR) responses. Therefore, robust control of LVAD relies greatly on the accurate estimation and prediction of HR. Our research team developed a new HR tracking algorithm that is robust to motion artifacts and measurement noise. The algorithm was validated with the data collected during different physical activities including walking, running, and weightlifting, and was compared with a few other popular techniques in the literature. It showed better performance in estimation accuracy, particularly when the sensing data were contaminated by strong motion artifacts.

The project benefited engineering education through new course material development, student training and mentoring, and retention of underrepresented groups. It provided students with an opportunity to obtain multidisciplinary training in engineering, medicine, and health care.
